subject: why LOW IT and not LOW EAT for -ly?
msgSnippet: I was reading http://adiabatic.github.io/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/ and noticed that many, if not all words ending in -ly were spelled -LOW IT instead of
messageBody:
I was reading http://adiabatic.github.io/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/ and noticed that many, if not all words ending in -ly were spelled -LOW IT instead of -LOW EAT. After turning to Read's manual and reading through the standard contractions I've largely ignored up until now, I discovered that he spells all the -ly endings with LOW IT instead of LOW EAT, too. According to him, "the dictionary suggests [IT]", whereas I'd have thought it'd suggest EAT — and I don't think this is particular to Southern California, either, if the couple of minutes I've spent listening to The Office (UK) clips are any guide. Read then goes on to explain that stressed final syllables get EAT (as expected).

Why would this spelling rule be put in? To save writers the trouble of lifting the pen when writing Senior Quikscript?
